title: Righteousness Through Faith
shortSummary: Romans chapter 3 addresses the universal sinfulness of humanity and the insufficiency of the law to justify. It reveals that righteousness comes freely through faith in Jesus Christ, available to both Jews and Gentiles alike, emphasizing God’s justice and grace in salvation.
timeline: c. AD 57 - Paul's Epistle to the Romans during his third missionary journey

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle who authored the letter to the Romans, explaining the doctrine of justification by faith.

keyCharacters.name: Jews
keyCharacters.description: God’s chosen people who received the oracles of God and the law, discussed in relation to their advantage and sinfulness.

keyCharacters.name: Gentiles
keyCharacters.description: Non-Jewish people who are also under sin and equally in need of justification through faith.

definitions.definition: The divine revelations and scriptures entrusted to the Jewish people.
The act by which God declares a sinner righteous by faith in Jesus Christ, apart from works of the law.
The atoning sacrifice of Christ that satisfies God’s wrath and turns away His judgment.
The principle that faith, not works, is the means by which believers are justified before God.

outline.heading: The Advantage of the Jew and the Problem of Unbelief
outline.description: Paul begins by affirming the special privileges of the Jews, especially receiving God’s oracles, but addresses the issue of some Jews’ unbelief and refutes the idea that sin could promote God’s righteousness.

outline.heading: Universal Sinfulness of Jews and Gentiles
outline.description: Paul declares that both Jews and Gentiles are under sin, quoting Old Testament scriptures to show that no one is righteous or seeks God on their own.

outline.heading: The Law’s Role and the Revelation of Righteousness by Faith
outline.description: The law reveals sin and brings guilt but cannot justify; it serves to stop all boasting and show the need for God’s righteousness.

outline.heading: Righteousness Apart from the Law Through Faith in Christ
outline.description: Paul explains that God’s righteousness is now revealed apart from the law, through faith in Jesus Christ, who is the propitiation for sins, demonstrating God’s justice and mercy.

outline.heading: Justification by Faith for All People
outline.description: Boasting is excluded because justification is by faith, not works; God is the God of both Jews and Gentiles, and faith upholds the law rather than nullifying it.

application: Recognize that all people, regardless of background, are sinners in need of God’s grace and cannot earn righteousness by their own efforts.
Place your full trust in Jesus Christ alone for justification, understanding that faith—not works—is the means of salvation.
Live humbly, knowing that boasting is excluded because salvation is a gift of grace through faith.
Respect and uphold God’s law as a guide for holy living, while rejoicing that faith fulfills the law’s righteous requirement.

keyVerses.text: For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God;
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the universal condition of sinfulness, setting the foundation for the need for salvation.

keyVerses.text: Being justified freely by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus:
keyVerses.significance: It highlights that justification is a free gift of God’s grace, made possible through Christ’s redemptive work.

keyVerses.text: Therefore we conclude that a man is justified by faith without the deeds of the law.
keyVerses.significance: This verse clearly states the core doctrine of justification by faith apart from works.

keyVerses.text: Do we then make void the law through faith? God forbid: yea, we establish the law.
keyVerses.significance: It affirms that faith does not nullify God’s law but upholds its true purpose.
